results.title: Jungfrukallan = The Virgin Spring
results.brief_description: Bergman won his first Academy Award for this brooding medieval tale based in an old Swedish ballad, closely comparable with the ‘Seventh seal’, examining the conflict between Christianity and pagnism rife throughout the Middle Ages. Set in beautiful 14th Century Sweden, it is the sombre, powerful fable of peasant parents (Max Von Sydow and Birgitta Valberg) whose daughter, a young virgin is brutally raped and murdered by swineherds after her half sister has invoked a pagan curse. By a bizarre twist of fate the murderers ask for food and shelter from the dead girl’s parents, who, discovering the truth about their lodgers, exact a chilling revenge. A cruel and sensational allegory, a tale of superstition, religious fervour, muurder and revenge, the formal simplicity and overt symbolism conspire to create an extraordinary metaphysical charge, aided by the the luminous, haunting black and white photography and Bergman’s meticulous direction.

results.title: Jumpy, the grasshopper
results.brief_description: Jumpy tells a story about a grasshopper and other insects as a basis for language/arts activities, and to enrich the study of insects. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Jumps and pole vaults
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Athletics”.
Slow-motion and stop-motion are used to demonstrate the running high jump, the running broad jump, the hop-step-and-jump, and the pole valut.

results.title: Jumping the gun
results.creator_credit: Murray Fahey, AFTRS and Jane Schneider
results.brief_description: Combining style from film noir, TV advertising imagery, Mills and Boon romance and Sydney ghetto realism, this is a farcical look at how one woman’s “morning after” fantasy turns into a tragi-comic nightmare.

results.title: Jumping molecules!
results.creator_credit: Michael Latham, Christopher Haws and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Konrad, the kitchen robot, shows how the energy in heat may be used to demonstrate the fundamentals of physics. Focuses on temperature and presents experiments using common household materials involving the kitchen refrigerator, cold water and hot water.

results.title: Jumping for Joy
results.creator_credit: Thames and Clyde Film Company, Educational Films of Scotland and Stanley Russell
results.brief_description: An introduction to trampolining. A semi-instructional film, it shows the growing popularity of the five basic landing positions, and shows suitable exercises for people of different ages. A section on the value of trampolining in rehabilitation work is also included.

results.title: Jump the fence
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Natalie Green and Lucy MacLaren
